bestBHT.bht: After Jesus appeared to the disciples, he asked for something to eat to prove his real corporeal form. He was given a piece of broiled fish, a common and frugal fare in ancient times. Interestingly, some manuscripts omit the mention of honeycomb, but it is believed that the omission was not an interpolation. The inclusion of broiled fish and the possible addition of honeycomb serve to emphasize that Jesus' post-resurrection body was physical and he could partake in ordinary human activities like eating.

Henry Alford: This was done farther to convince them of his real corporeity.
The omission of the words and of an honeycomb in the best MSS. is remarkable: see var. readd.
The words could hardly have been an interpolation.
Marvin Vincent: Broiled. Only here in New Testament.
Of an honey - comb. The best texts omit.
Philip Schaff: These words are omitted in many ancient authorities, and rejected by some modern editors.
We prefer to retain them, since there are a number of reasons to account for their being left out.
...more to account for their being put in by the copyists.
Archibald T. Robertson: A piece of broiled fish (ιχθυος οπτου μερος)... The best old documents omit 'and a honeycomb' (κα απο μελισσιου κηριου).
John Gill: And they gave him a piece of a broiled fish... which was left by them at supper."
Being fishermen, most of them, this was agreeable food to them."
And of an honeycomb... not to eat with the fish, but after it.

bhtAttempts.bht: After Jesus appeared to the disciples, he asked for something to eat to prove his real corporeal form. He was given a piece of broiled fish, a common and frugal fare in ancient times. Interestingly, some manuscripts omit the mention of honeycomb, but it is believed that the omission was not an interpolation. The inclusion of broiled fish and the possible addition of honeycomb serve to emphasize that Jesus' post-resurrection body was physical and he could partake in ordinary human activities like eating.

After appearing to the disciples, Jesus requested something to eat as proof of his corporeal existence. He was given a piece of broiled fish, a common fare in ancient times. Although some manuscripts omit the mention of honeycomb, it is believed that this exclusion was not an interpolation. The inclusion of the broiled fish and possible addition of honeycomb served to highlight the physical nature of Jesus' post-resurrection body and his ability to engage in ordinary human activities, such as eating.

After appearing to the disciples, Jesus asked for food to prove his corporeal form, and he was given broiled fish. Though some manuscripts omit the mention of honeycomb, it is believed that this exclusion was not an interpolation. The inclusion of the broiled fish emphasizes that Jesus' post-resurrection body was physical and capable of performing ordinary human actions like eating. Eating the broiled fish served as a tangible demonstration of Jesus' resurrection and his continued presence with his disciples.

After Jesus appeared to the disciples, he asked for food as evidence of his real corporeal form. A piece of broiled fish was given to him, reflecting the common frugal fare of that time. Although some manuscripts omit the reference to honeycomb, it is unlikely that this was an interpolation. The inclusion of the broiled fish highlights the physicality of Jesus' post-resurrection body and his ability to engage in ordinary human activities. This act of eating demonstrates Jesus' tangible presence and his fulfillment of the Messianic prophecies.

After Jesus appeared to the disciples, he requested food as proof of his real corporeal form. They offered him a piece of broiled fish, a common frugal fare in ancient times. Though some manuscripts omit the mention of honeycomb, it is unlikely that this was an interpolation. The inclusion of the broiled fish underscores the physicality of Jesus' post-resurrection body, showcasing his ability to engage in ordinary human activities. This act of eating validates his resurrection and establishes his continued presence with the disciples.
